For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations Mischa Dennis D'Andrea. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. On today's call, we have Fabrizio Freda, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tracey Travis, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fabrizio and Tracey will review our third quarter results and full year outloo
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. On today's call, we have Fabrizio Freda, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tracey Travis, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fabrizio and Tracey will review our third quarter results and full year outlook and then discuss the new initiatives we announced this morning called Leaning Forward. 
Since many of our remarks contained forward-looking statements, let me refer you to our press release, and our reports filed with the SEC, where you will find factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from these forward-looking statements 
To facilitate the discussion of our underlying business, our 9-month and full-year comparisons have been adjusted for the impact of the prior year implementation of our strategic modernization initiatives, and the discussion of our financial results and expectations before restructuring another charges 
You can find reconciliations between GAAP and non-GAAP figures in our press release and on the Investor Relations section of our website. [Operator Instructions]
And now, I would like to turn the call over to Fabrizio.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Dennis and good morning, everyone. In the third quarter, we delivered solid performance withgains particularly from our makeup category and international business. In constant currencies, sales grew 6% and earnings per share rose 5% before charges
componenttext:
Thanks, Dennis and good morning, everyone. In the third quarter, we delivered solid performance withgains particularly from our makeup category and international business. In constant currencies, sales grew 6% and earnings per share rose 5% before charges to $0.76. 
Based on our results to date, we're on track to achieve our sales and earnings guidance for the full fiscal year, excluding charges 
We continue to benefit from a highly diversified business with multiple engines of growth and the flexibility to move investment quickly to support areas that provide the best returns. We continued to fuel makeup a vibrant weapon category where we have achieved constant currency double-digit gains every quarter this fiscal year 
Social media is helping to drive makeup sales with how to do videos, tips from consumers that influences and beautiful visuals of makeup transformations. Our company has thousands of talented makeup artists who are a competitive advantage for our brands and help drive consumption through personal licensing stores as well as online where they can demonstrate the artistry to the broader audience 
M-A-C Instagram, for example, features photos submitted by its global artists illustrating their creativity and talent stride to products and trends. This kind of social media interaction creates an ongoing dialogue between the brand and its consumers and help drive sales 
We are the largest company in global prestige makeup and all our makeup brands grew this quarter. Each of our 3 diverse makeup focused brands has a distinct character and channel profile; for example, our third -- one-third of M-A-C sales came from its freestanding stores. A majority of Bobbi Brown salesl came from the global stores and Smashbox has a strong presence in specialty multi retailers and there is further opportunity for growth across all prestige channels 
In addition to its popular fragrance collections, our Tom Ford brand has a fast-growing and much desired makeup business. Sales of Tom Ford luxury makeup products rose more than 50% 
Sale order in Clinique also achieved global growth in cap portfolios. Estée Lauder delivered good momentum in the European region as its double foundation continued to be a strong seller. In North America, the brand launch the Estee Edit exclusivity in several stores and on sephora.com. The millionaire of targeted line generated the recent media attention and there is a full cadence of strong promotional activities planned throughout the fourth quarter 
At Clinique, the brand extended its successful collection with new formulas and attracted young consumers with a digital campaign that included interactive music videos with a raising pop star. 
Growth in fragrance continue to come from our luxury sense. Jo Malone and Tom Ford had terrific results. Both brands generated double-digit growth in every region. The success of these brand supports our strategy to position our fragrance portfolio toward a profitable in area where we are gaining share 
Our luxury fragrance brands, Le Labo and Frédéric Malle, contributed higher sales, has been the collection of fragrances 
Recently, we acquired a sophisticated -based brand that we believe further strengthen our leadership in fast-growing luxury fragrances 
Turning to our geographies. Our international business was staller and virtually every market grew. During the quarter, I visited several countries to grow consumer sentiment and visit stores. One trip was in the U.K., which had a robust sales in the quarter, far exceeding prestige beauty growth  While that I spent time in Birmingham and so how our brand successfully tailored that product to the city's diverse multicultural population.
Consumers in the U.K. have a great passion for beauty and our brands have responded in ways that appeal to a wide range of demographics which has helped reinforce our leadership position in this market. The European region remained robust with growth in nearly every country and particularly, France and Italy, where all brands contributed to a double-digit increase 
the tragic attacks in Paris, Turkey and Brussels understandably dampened some tourist activities in the quarter. But I'm proud of that tremendous trends and resilience our organization in this country showed during this very difficult times. 
Although, fewer tourists contributed to a falloff in retail sales in French Airports following the Paris attack, our total net sales for sales for the quarter were strong, enjoying the results of our diversification strategy by region, category, brand and type of airport 
And retail sales in China were solid and broad-based. They rose double digits in house of the top 30 trial retail markets in the world. 
Currency fluctuations continue to affect travel patterns. In our travel business, we continue to see stronger growth in some markets where the currency was weakening, including Japan, Australia, or Canada due to a greater number of inbound tourists. Weak currencies in Brazil and Russia led to a decline in travel by those population and affected the sales in the travel corridors that they, frequent. However, local market sales in these 2 countries grew double-digits, as more consumer purchase products close to their homes. 
Adjusted return from Korea a few days ago, it was amazed by the energy and excitement there, that beauty produces, since the fear of nerves is abutted, tourists are returning, especially the Chinese. Our business in Korea has turned around very nicely from a year ago, up double digits this quarter, and I was very pleased to see that we're gaining share 
Demand for makeup is exhilarating strongly and our brands are successfully competing head to head with Korean brands. 4 of our brands introduced cushion comforts, which are extremely popular with Korean consumers. Bobbi Brown's Cushion Comfort did so well it became 15% off its Korea business and contributed to the brand's foundation sales doubling in the country 
During my visit, I met our partners at an impressive brand that is seeing strong demand and insights into consumer desires and opportunities for growth 
As I visited stores in I couldn't help, but notice the sales of luxury fragrances are booming, including our own Jo Malone brand. I'm excited about the opportunity this trend holds for the newer fragrance brands in our portfolio. We recently launched GLAMGLOW in Korea and avid consumers are actively using social media to the brand and. Korea is a center of innovation for beauty and there are many new trends and ideas that our brands can leverage and bring to consumers in other areas of the world.
Looking now with our emerging markets. Our China business was healthy, as most brands grew solidly and retail sales gained momentum. The online channel had the fastest growth and accounted for nearly 10% of sales. Sales in fragrance continue to accelerate creating greater diversification in our Chinese business. As an example, more than doubled with strong momentum in both department stores and freestanding stores 
Our other emerging markets continue to generate excellent growth, rising 20% among the best performance were South Africa or Brazil. M-A-C continues to be a trailblazer in Africa has introduced prestige beauty products and personalized services. It has entered many countries in New Zealand, most recently Zambia 
To fuel of company's growth -- global momentum, we continued invested in fast-growing channels. We opened new freestanding stores and launched several E&M commerce sites for our brands, mostly with retailers. GLAMGLOW, for example, began selling its products on Nostrum with website. We also increased our presence in specialty. In the U.S. Clinique continued expanding in all stuff. Estée Lauder launched its Estée Edit product line in Sephora and several several brands added more locations in Bluemercury. opened a new specialty concept in Shanghai and several of our brands are present 
Our creativity and innovation were center to accomplishments in the quarter. Estée Lauder advanced powerful mask was well received, particularly, in Asia and boosted the brands important Advanced Night Repair franchise. Clinique eye cream, which brightens and primes the eye area for makeup did bought it in -- exclusively in Sephora in the United States and was the #1 eye cream there in February and March 
Beyond products, our brand continue to forge creative collaborations. M-A-C is designing a makeup collection inspired by the singer Celena. Estée Lauder is teaming up with foster designer, Victoria Beckham, for a full cosmetic collection. 
This collaboration brings great to our brand, especially on social media, and we them to grow new consumers.
Now, I will turn the call over to Tracey to give more details on the quarter.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Fabrizio, and good morning, everyone. First, I will briefly review our fiscal 2016 third quarter results, and then I will cover our expectations for the full year. As a reminder, my commentary excludes the impact of restructuring and other char
componenttext:
Thank you, Fabrizio, and good morning, everyone. First, I will briefly review our fiscal 2016 third quarter results, and then I will cover our expectations for the full year. As a reminder, my commentary excludes the impact of restructuring and other charges. 
Net sales for the third quarter were to $2.66 billion, up 6% in constant currency compared to the prior year. Our newest brand acquisitions contributed approximately 10 basis points of the sales growth 
As Fabrizio mentioned, our international business remained quite strong as nearly all of our international markets grew this quarter, led by the Europe, Middle East and Africa region. Net sales in EMEA rose 11% in constant currency, with double-digit growth in most developed and emerging markets. The region continues to benefit in part from the weak euro, making in a more attractive tourist destination as well as from the benefits of strong execution of its strategic initiatives 
The U.K., Nordic and Italy were the largest contributors to grow among the developed markets in the region and the Middle East, Russia, South Africa and Central Europe led double-digit gains in emerging markets in the region. Our online business was particularly strong across all EMEA markets this quarter 
Our net sales in the global travel retail channel rose 9%, reflecting strong retail trends in most countries in Europe and Asia, which were partially offset by continued net sales decline in Hong Kong, Brazil and The United States. Overall, passenger traffic growth in travel retail across all regions remained solid, despite shifts in consumption patterns between countries due to currencies 
Sales in the Asia Pacific region grew 5% in constant currency. Every market in that region grew, except in Hong Kong, which was down double digits. Korea was the largest contributor to net sales growth rising 14% in the quarter followed closely by Japan, Australia and Taiwan. China rose 5% led by 70% growth in E&M sales. Online sales across all APAC markets grow sharply this quarter. 
Our net sales in Hong Kong declined more than we had anticipated as tourists from the Chinese mainland continue to decrease. 
Excluding Hong Kong, the region sales would've grow nearly 9% 
Net sales in the Americas increased 2% in constant currency. Brazil, Mexico and Canada all saw strong double-digit growth. As currencies in these countries continued to weaken against the dollar, local market consumption remained strong. Sales in the U.S. rose low single digits. Continued strength in our online business, specialty multi and high-end department store channels was largely offset by sharp declines in tourist-driven retail doors and continued softness in traffic in the brick-and-mortar business of midtier department stores 
Once again, makeup sales led product category growth rising 11% in constant currency. Double-digit growth from M-A-C, Smashbox and Tom Ford led the increase, while particularly strength -- while particular strength in the and foundation categories drove makeup growth at Bobbi Brown, Clinique and Estée Lauder this quarter.
Sales of fragrance rose 7% in constant currency. Double-digit gains from our luxury portfolio, Jo Malone, Tom Ford and Le Labo contributed to the majority of the growth. The Michael Kors Gold collection and Tory Burch stood out among the designer fragrances, the strength of the high-end of the fragrance category was partially offset by lower fragrances sales from Estée Lauder and the remaining designer fragrances 
Haircare sales increased 3% in constant currency. The data benefited from the initial shipments of its new and body for men product as well as higher sales of more recent launches and existing products. The brands of the new doors in travel retail and added and freestanding stores in Europe. Bumble and bumble experienced solid growth in all channels.
Skin care sales were flat in constant currency reflecting the continued weakness in Hong Kong and the ongoing shift and increased consumer spending from skin care to makeup. Additionally, Estée Lauder skincare business declined slightly in the quarter due to tough comparisons with prior year launches in the U.S. and in Asia. There were many bright spots in our portfolio for skin care. La Mer Origins group skin care in double digits, as did skin care lines of our M.A.C and Bobbi Brown makrup brands 
Our gross margin increased 50 basis points to 81% of sales, the improvement came primarily from supply chain savings and lower promotional expenses partially offset by channel and category mix. Operating expenses, as a percent of sales, increased 110 basis points to 66% compared to the prior year quarter 
Selling and store operations cost to support our retail store growth as well as the general and initiative costs primarily from employee-related costs, consulting fees and our prior acquisitions drove most of the increases. These were partially offset by our value creation from our strategic modernization initiative and a deferral of some advertising and promotional expenses to the fourth quarter to support higher expected sales growth in the quarter 
As a result, operating income decreased less than 1% to $399.2 million and operating margin fell 60 basis points to 15% due entirely to foreign exchange. On a constant currency basis, operating income grew 3% 
Net earnings also decreased approximately 1% below the prior year quarter to $274.9 million. Diluted EPS of $0.73 was 2% above the prior-year reflecting the benefit of a lower share count. Our stronger-than-expected EPS was largely driven by a combination of continued expense management and a delay in some advertising and promotional spending for Estée Lauder and Clinique to the fourth quarter 
Earnings per share for the quarter include $0.02 of dilution from acquisitions and $0.03 of unfavorable currency translation. On a constant currency basis, EPS increased 5% 
Let me now turn to our outlook for the full fiscal year. The sales shift related to last year's SMI rollout will impact full year comparisons to the prior year. I will discuss our expectations adjusting for the impact of the shift, as always. Our forecasted growth rates, both before and after the shift, impact are available in today's earnings release. Also excluded is impact of restructuring and other charges.
For the full year, we expected sales to continue -- to grow 7% to 8% in constant currency, including 50 basis points from acquisitions. Currency translation is expected to negatively impact of full year sales growth by approximately 5 percentage points. Our estimate assumes spot exchange rates as of the end of April of 1.14 for the euro, 1.44 for the pound and 1.09 for the yen for the the remainder of the fiscal year 
Diluted EPS is now expected to range between $3.09 and $3.14, or $0.02 more than our last guidance that you, reflecting a slight moderation in the currency impact. Adverse currency translation is now projected to affect the EPS by about $0.27. Excluding the currency impact, we continue to expect EPS growth of 10% to 12%. Our EPS range includes approximately $0.05 of dilution from acquisitions 
Our strong performance today gives us a confidence to invest more in the fourth quarter to support additional advertising and promotion, primarily, for Estée Lauder and Clinique. While we continue to pursue value creation from our SMI program, which is now expected to deliver $175 million of cost savings this year, we also look for ways to further improve our cost leverage in the future 
Fabrizio will now discuss the initiative we announced a our press release today.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tracey. The multifaceted initiatives that we called leading beauty forwards is designed to provide additional fuel for long-term growth and profitability. Each will build on our strong foundation and leverage capabilities we have developed in i
componenttext:
Thank you, Tracey. The multifaceted initiatives that we called leading beauty forwards is designed to provide additional fuel for long-term growth and profitability. Each will build on our strong foundation and leverage capabilities we have developed in important areas driving our business including digital, retail and creative. 
Leading beauty forward will support the continuing success of our strategy in an increasingly fast-paced complex and competitive prestige beauty environment. It is designed to sustain our momentum by reducing costs and freeing up more resources to invest in brands capability and most profitable opportunities, while better leveraging our growth. 
As we look towards the future, we believe the best way to capture the growth opportunity of tomorrow is being proactive today. These initiative is carefully measured next step in our long-term strategy that will allow us to continue to lead in the prestige beauty industry. We expect leading beauty forward to sustain our sales operating margin and earning per share growth beyond the goals we have set throughout fiscal year 2018. Clearly, how we do business today and how we must be prepared to do business in the future is very different from what it was just 7 years ago when we launched our current strategy. The fast-moving landscape requires a mindset and a way of operating that increases speed and flexibility is created, streamlined, cost efficient are designed to serve global consumers in new ways 
To that end, as part of leading beauty forward, we plan to redesign select areas of our go to market organizations in the regions, affiliates and brands to increase agility and strengthen that capabilities. As more of our consumer engagement moves to digital platforms, the markets will need the tools and authority to respond quickly to opportunities and bring our expertise in local relevance closer to consumer 
Stronger skills and innovation digital, social media and creative capabilities will allow them to differentiate our unique brands even farther by tailoring products and services to specific consumer segments and channels. We also will redesign select corporate functions to increase their efficiencies by making them leaner, scalable and less costly, while continue to deliver excellent services to our brand and businesses. We are evaluating the creation of a global and regional shared services among certain functions to simplify processes and focus on more strategic activities. We also plan to continue to optimize some of our supply chain operations to create a more efficient structure. These actions are expected to reduce our operating expenses, freeing up resources to invest in our brands, channel, consumer facing activities and potential acquisitions 
An important goal of leading beauty forward is to support and grow our brands. To accomplish this, we'll invest in activities that will resonate the consumers including the innovation to develop new product and services, unique point of sales assets, effective social media dialogues and compelling advertising. We will also support our newly acquired brands to expand their presence and products and continue to build our small and medium-size brands, so they become leaders in the industry 
As employees focus more fully on being creative and strategic, we will enhance our learning and developing programs. So they have the best skills to lead in critical areas. The redesign will regrettably include reducing position in some areas. We also expect to add talent in the departments we plan to strengthen and to retain all other employees. In total, we estimate at this time, a global net reduction of approximately 900 to 1,200 positions, which is about 2.5% of our current workforce 
As the company continues to grow and invest in new positions in the future, the improved process from these initiatives are expected also to better leverage future productivity. We're launching leading beauty forward from a position of exceptional strength. Since we began our new strategy cycle, our sales have increased by more than 50% and our growth rate has outpaced that of global prestige beauty. Key to this performance is the much more diversified and balanced business we have created, with growth engines across our brands, categories, channels and geographies. 
Within size from our 10-year we anticipated many of the trends influencing the industry's rise. We also modernize our processes and technology infrastructure. Our strategy modernization initiative has been deployed through most of our organization creating greater visibility to information that let us manage our business in a more cost-efficient manner. We developed a wider spectrum of capabilities, strengthening our talents in areas such as R&D, supply chain, information technology, retail, digital and consumer insight. 
Leading beauty forward is designed to build on these achievements to further increase our efficiency and effectiveness. Global prestige beauty is striding, growing industry with new channels, emerging geographies at the influence of younger consumer. With the convenience of the Internet, the passion of specialty multi retailers dedicated to beauty, particularly, in the U.S. how consumers is changing rapidly in competition has intensified. Lower barrier to entry resulted in more than 250 new niche brands launching around the word last year and the sheer number of beauty products buying for consumer's attention is vastly increasing 
The design of our new structure should generate greater productivity to better cost leverage of our sales growth. Importantly, leading beauty forward will create ongoing savings and reinvestment to help continue our momentum in this fast growing and more competitive market, which should mean greater sustainability and less risk in meeting our future growth platform 
As the global leader in prestige beauty, we are posed to take advantage of opportunities that lie ahead by taking charge in leading change. Leading beauty forward further positions our company to continue winning in this rapidly changing arena where the ability to anticipate developments adn react swiftly and nimbly is more essential than ever. We expect to sustain our strong growth and lead not only our company but whole of the prestige beauty forward to a greater heights. Tracey?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. So as Fabrizio just discussed, leading beauty forward is a multiyear initiative designed to help us fuel growth momentum and create more efficient assistant to sustain our margin progression beyond fiscal 2018. During the course of this initi
componenttext:
Thank you. So as Fabrizio just discussed, leading beauty forward is a multiyear initiative designed to help us fuel growth momentum and create more efficient assistant to sustain our margin progression beyond fiscal 2018. 
During the course of this initiative, over the last few years, we expect to take charges of approximately $600 million to $700 million. We expect to begin realizing initial benefits from the program in fiscal 2018, but we'll continue to maintain our flexibility to invest in opportunities and mitigate risks 
At this time, we do not expect this to affect the long range guidance we provided last summer other than the related restructuring charges. Once fully implemented, we expect to generate annualized benefits -- net benefits of $200 million to $300 million currently anticipated to be fully realized after fiscal 2019. We expect to reinvest a portion of those savings behind the capabilities we need that Fabrizio just discussed to continue to succeed in the rapidly changing global prestige beauty environment 
We'll, as we usually do, update our 3-year strategic outlook and share our goals in August. The update will include the impact of these initiatives, any adjustment to our strategy since last year, and the addition of recently acquired brand and changes in currency rate assumptions. 
We're pleased with our results so far this year and we believe leading beauty forward will play an important role in supporting our continued sustained growth momentum for the long-term 
And that concludes our prepared remarks. We'll be happy to take your questions at this time.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Nik Modi from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question today comes from Nik Modi from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Fabrizio I had a question on innovation. If you would've characterized the pipeline going back 5 years, 3 years and then today. How would you explain it to us? And -- and I'm really coming at point of it takes time usually for the pipeline to get fille
componenttext: So Fabrizio I had a question on innovation. If you would've characterized the pipeline going back 5 years, 3 years and then today. How would you explain it to us? And -- and I'm really coming at point of it takes time usually for the pipeline to get filled versus the products actually hitting the marketplace, so I just wanted to get some context on how you feel about the pipeline today versus maybe 5 years ago?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I see it's very strong. I see our pipeline best was 5 years ago, I would say, it's almost doubled in terms of the power of extra business. We have a very clear internal process where we look for sufficiency of our innovation pipeline versus our next 3 yea
componenttext: I see it's very strong. I see our pipeline best was 5 years ago, I would say, it's almost doubled in terms of the power of extra business. We have a very clear internal process where we look for sufficiency of our innovation pipeline versus our next 3 years, 5 years goals. And I can tell you, we consider our innovation pipeline more than sufficient. Now the characteristic of the pipeline has changed in some way also. First of all, today the pipeline is much richer in makeup because as you heard that the makeup category is, in this moment, fast-growing in the world and also very fast-changing. So there's some outstanding innovation pipeline in makeup and the makeup pipelines tends to be down by many smaller products versus few of a big products, which is more typical of the skin care pipeline, so that's a change. And we have adjusted to the change. Our skin care pipeline is strong, but again, within skin care, the pipeline is more focused of what we call instant benefit skin care versus the long-term antiaging and that's changed. And third, and probably very, very important, our pipeline in the fragrance business has changed and its done by much more high-end luxury artisanal fragrances, which will allow us, in my opinion, to continue to gain market share in the high-end profitable fragrance business. And finally, in hair care, our pipeline, particularly in the styling and more profitable part of hair care, is stronger than ever. So in that, I feel positive about the sufficiency of the pipeline and also I feel positive by the the fit of our pipeline to the future of the markets as identified by our compass.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Dara Mohsenian from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is from Dara Mohsenian from Morgan Stanley.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Obviously you are seeing very strong growth in makeup, as is the category, can you discuss how long you think this cycle of makeup category strength can continue as you look over the next few years and what's driving the category growth? And then, on the
componenttext: Obviously you are seeing very strong growth in makeup, as is the category, can you discuss how long you think this cycle of makeup category strength can continue as you look over the next few years and what's driving the category growth? And then, on the e-commerce side, how sustainable do you think the strong growth is that you're seeing on that business, you were kind of earlier than a lot of peers and focusing resources, they are on that channel, so I guess, is there any risk going forward that competitors start to catch up with you or do you think you're widening your gap versus peers in terms of the way you manage the business?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. On makeup, first of all, I believe this is a long-term trend. The makeup category is growing driven by several aspects. The first one is that the Asian consumer, the Asian women are becoming more avid users of makeup. And so this is an enormous amoun
componenttext: Yes. On makeup, first of all, I believe this is a long-term trend. The makeup category is growing driven by several aspects. The first one is that the Asian consumer, the Asian women are becoming more avid users of makeup. And so this is an enormous amount of growth potentially that was developed -- it is developing now and will continue to develop in the next years. The second big trend is that the millionaires are on an average using more makeup than the previous generation, so there is an increase of conceptual per Individual in all markets, including developed markets and this is a long time trend, also because what is it driving the more user to makeup is what historically has been our strength and our business model, which is education and customization. And now the education is available also via online, exactly our e-commerce activities and via social media, which is booming the amount of how to different trends, et cetera. So the combination of this more amount of trends information and how-to information with the millennial generation point of view is pushing makeup up. I think, this will continue for a long period. In terms of our activity in e-commerce, we continue to do very well. I think, we gained substantial competitive advantage, but not only in the execution in market also in the capabilities. We have a very strong e-commerce team that is developing amazing work which are divided into technology people that can develop sites and develop activity in a very fast pace around the world from our centralized offices in New York in a very -- with investment in now will payout in the long-term that we have done in the previous years. And we have great quality of execution in the creative side. So on top of that number of sites, the ability to penetrate the markets, frankly, we have the capability and the quality of execution that for the time being set us aside, in my opinion, from the industry.Tracey?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we also have a very good partnership with all of our retailers around world to make sure that our products are displayed and presented well on the retailer.com sites as well.
componenttext: And we also have a very good partnership with all of our retailers around world to make sure that our products are displayed and presented well on the retailer.com sites as well.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Olivia Tong from Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question is from Olivia Tong from Bank of America.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I wanted to go back into advertising a little bit, for the particular -- for this particular quarter, because coming of the quarter you probably plan to increase A&P support in the businesses,  of course, continue driving sales and support some of
componenttext: First, I wanted to go back into advertising a little bit, for the particular -- for this particular quarter, because coming of the quarter you probably plan to increase A&P support in the businesses,  of course, continue driving sales and support some of the product launches, but the sales growth did decelerate a little bit -- probably a little bit more than people had expected. So can you help with some -- provide a little bit more insight on how you go about making decisions on A&P spend, because that line just continue to move around a fair bit quarter-to-quarter? And then also, in terms of the Chinese tourism, do think you're making up the shortfall in Hong Kong from lack of Chinese tourists in other areas?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- first of all, in terms of the phase of the quarter. We continue to believe that we will deliver the fiscal year in the 7% to 8% range, which means if you look at the numbers that, we assume actually in acceleration of the sales trend in the four
componenttext:
So the -- first of all, in terms of the phase of the quarter. We continue to believe that we will deliver the fiscal year in the 7% to 8% range, which means if you look at the numbers that, we assume actually in acceleration of the sales trend in the fourth quarter. So the sales in the quarter depend a lot by initiatives, launches and what happens in specific markets. And the way we take A&P decisions is -- really we base the decision of -- if we believe there is enough rate of return on that investment in that moment. For example, in quarter 3, the things that we saw going less strong that we expect that was Hong Kong. And so when we had markets that decreased the growth significantly, we do decrease our spending there and we keep the spending for better moments where that is better market traction. So what you're seeing in this quarter, very specifically, reduced spending in Hong Kong from our side. The second area where we saw a less traction was U.S. mid-year department store brick-and-mortar where we clearly saw less traction together with all the tourist doors in the U.S. that particularly, influenced by the absence of Brazilians and Russians that was a very dramatic change. So when we see these dramatic changes, we obviously adjust our investment. The second reason was, in this case, very specific is some product launch initiative, so Clinique that we decided to move in supporting them in the fourth quarter, which is the other reason why we're moving the investment from one quarter to another. Personally, I see these as a strength. We have the agility to move our key investment by quarter depending on the market situation and the broader launches situation and these make us more efficient and more effective, and we stay consistent on our year goal, that we will commit to do our best to deliver, does not change by quarter, actually we see agility and flexibility as strengths.
On the Chinese consumers, now that we are definitely doing much better with Chinese consumer in other areas where they are going, for example, in Europe as we are seeing there is a growth of our European business, which is partially driven by tourists and the tourists are also Chinese, we are seeing Korea coming back and Japan being pretty strong. So yes, we recover some of the sales, however, not all of that. We have a very high market share in Hong Kong, very very high market share. And our market share, for example in Japan is half of the market share we have in Hong Kong. So in that situation, we obviously cannot recover the Hong Kong losses completely in other areas and that's what you're seeing in this moment as a phenomenon, but this is a temporary phenomenon and as soon as Hong Kong will stabilize in other markets where we are now building market share, like Korea, will achieve the levels we believe are achievable, the things will accelerate again.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Bill Schmitz from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is from Bill Schmitz from Deutsche Bank.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you just talk about some of the U.S. NPD trends, because it's not just Estée Lauder but the bigger brands like still continue to lose market share from some of the smaller niche brands. So is there a strategy in place to find a way to, kind of, help
componenttext: Can you just talk about some of the U.S. NPD trends, because it's not just Estée Lauder but the bigger brands like still continue to lose market share from some of the smaller niche brands. So is there a strategy in place to find a way to, kind of, help them? And then, maybe most, I don't want to say problematic, but it seems like M-A-C is declining quite a bit in the U.S., actually quite a bit, but it's declining. So can you just talk about the M-A-C U.S. versus international split and if the international growth can offset some of the softness in the U.S.?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think starting for M-A-C, M-A-C is really doing very, very well, internationally. M-A-C is growing strong double-digits in every single market of the world and these -- the temporary flattening of the retail trend in the U.S. is being more than off
componenttext:
Yes, I think starting for M-A-C, M-A-C is really doing very, very well, internationally. M-A-C is growing strong double-digits in every single market of the world and these -- the temporary flattening of the retail trend in the U.S. is being more than offset by a blooming international business. The flattening of the U.S. is -- the temporary flattening of the U.S. trend is to -- driven by 2 aspects: One, as I said, is the fact that the lower traffic in midtier department store is one of the driver and the other is tourists. I mean, M-A-C business is driven by tourists of the world that this is the U.S. in a significant way because the brand is very, very popular around the word. So the important decrease of tourists, particularly Brazilians and Russians, as I said, is temporary, limited the retail of M-A-C, also because these tourists were very strong in the base period that we're comparing this to. Overall, in total, M-A-C 
continues to be absolutely one of the strong drivers of our success around the world and we have programs to ensure that this will continue. In terms of the success of the small size brands in the U.S. This is a fact that, as I explained in my prepared remarks, that the combination of easy access to consumers and more availability of investment lower interest rates created a lot of new launches of brands and the possibility of social media to bring attention of the consumers has taken down the barriers to entry. So the way we're reacting is, first of all, reinforcing the business in our strong brands. Second, participating to this with our midsize smaller brands, including acquisitions. I mean, Smashbox was one of these brands when we acquired these brands and now in fact its growing double-digit in the context of these. And then finally, is the diversification of our distribution with freestanding store, more specialty, continued success of online and our support to midtier department store to accelerate to reinforcer business model to be able to better attract millionaires and better activate the floor in order to become even more competitive of this development of smaller brands and all the new channels. This is one of the changes that I was describing before that requires adjustment in capabilities and investments in supporting our brand's growth.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Faucher from JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Faucher from JP Morgan.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we take a look at your margin performance over the half couple of years, it seems to have moderated a little bit here in terms of the year-over-year increases and I realize there is FX as well as the acquisition impact in that, but it really seems to p
componenttext: If we take a look at your margin performance over the half couple of years, it seems to have moderated a little bit here in terms of the year-over-year increases and I realize there is FX as well as the acquisition impact in that, but it really seems to particularly since the end of 2010 to 2013 restructuring program. And so I guess, as we look at the new restructuring program, is that a sign maybe that the incremental margins on organic revenue growth is lower than what it was and I guess, if that's the case, there has been a discussion and you guys have talked about the cost of growth not having gone higher, but the math would seem to indicate that, again, maybe that incremental margin isn't as high as it had been historically. Any thoughts on that?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, first of all, I'll let Tracey give answer. But first of all, I want to say that this fiscal year, we have 50 points -- half a margin point, just affected by currency and 30 basis points just by acquisitions. So 80 are attracted by currency and acquis
componenttext: Yes, first of all, I'll let Tracey give answer. But first of all, I want to say that this fiscal year, we have 50 points -- half a margin point, just affected by currency and 30 basis points just by acquisitions. So 80 are attracted by currency and acquisitions. So yes, that's a new factor in the margin evolution. But then the combination of our business and cost savings is actually producing the power to continue growing margin. Obviously, if currency and acquisition will stop affecting it negatively, this will be more visible. The other thing is, there is also a mix change in our business. So we have more freestanding stores and we have more makeup versus skin care that also are changing the input of mix in our business, so we need to continue to deliver our growth, we need to become more efficient and effective and manage our overall cost reduction better. And that's part of what we are announcing today and we are going to do. Tracey?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, those are the 2 differentiators, John, in terms of the timeframe that you referred to, but the restructuring program previously, which allowed us to invest back of the business and really drive and support what was skin care moment, particularly,
componenttext: I think, those are the 2 differentiators, John, in terms of the timeframe that you referred to, but the restructuring program previously, which allowed us to invest back of the business and really drive and support what was skin care moment, particularly, in Asia and the period post that corresponded with a slowdown in nation and Asian consumption, particularly, in China and Hong Kong, as Fabrizio spoke about, which certainly slowed our skin care business, particularly with our large brand like Estée Lauder and to a lesser extend Clinique. So that is a margin difference in terms of our business performance relative to our previous timeframe. One of the things that the lead beauty forward program does for us, because we are -- and certainly our compass -- our tenure compass has allowed us to continue to understand that there are very significant growth opportunities for us from a total  company standpoint. It allows us the freedom to invest more in those is opportunities irrespective of the margin and deliver our margin goals in -- well into the future. And so it's a very exciting program. But certainly, it is proactive on our part looking forward in terms of where the growth opportunities are and making sure that we can support them with capabilities, we can support them with other investments and still drive the business and the profit expectations.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Lauren from Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Our next question is from Lauren from Piper Jaffray.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a couple for you this morning. And the first question I have, I guess, you have seen so Q4 related to Estée and Clinique. Is that type of specific product line introductions in response to the other channel? And then, secondarily, just examples of
componenttext: I have a couple for you this morning. And the first question I have, I guess, you have seen so Q4 related to Estée and Clinique. Is that type of specific product line introductions in response to the other channel? And then, secondarily, just examples of majority, is that largely in the product development and marketing pipeline?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think on the A&P, Fabrizio did speak with that -- speak to that a little earlier, Lauren. It is tied somewhat to  some of the launches that we're expecting from, particularly, Estée Lauder and Clinique in the fourth quarter, it's also tied a bit to
componenttext: So I think on the A&P, Fabrizio did speak with that -- speak to that a little earlier, Lauren. It is tied somewhat to  some of the launches that we're expecting from, particularly, Estée Lauder and Clinique in the fourth quarter, it's also tied a bit to some stores that slipped in terms of store openings from Q3 into Q4, primarily, related to M-A-C. So those are the primary drivers. And as Fabrizio mentioned, also previously the slowdown in Hong Kong and a couple of other market slowdown, North America, we see in the last few years, postholiday traffic has been quite slow, and it has taken longer to start to see traffic flow back into particularly, the department store channel and particularly, the midtier department store channel. So those factors are what caused us to think that the A&P that we had initially planned for Q3 would be better spent in Q4.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Javier Escalante with Consumer Edge Research.
componenttext: Our next question is from Javier Escalante with Consumer Edge Research.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question has to do with your expansion of freestanding stores my -- in the third quarter. My understanding is that you had opened 90 out of the 250 target that you setup for the year by second quarter, 90 by the second quarter. So if you can tell us ho
componenttext: My question has to do with your expansion of freestanding stores my -- in the third quarter. My understanding is that you had opened 90 out of the 250 target that you setup for the year by second quarter, 90 by the second quarter. So if you can tell us how many stores that you opened in the third quarter in what regions, what was their contribution to growth? And whether what is the slotted for Q4 is what -- is going to drive the acceleration of the topline growth?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Javier, we opened net 25 stores in the third quarter, a little bit less than what we had expected and as I just mentioned, more swift to the fourth quarter. We don't comment on the incremental sales by channel related to growth from our different chann
componenttext: So Javier, we opened net 25 stores in the third quarter, a little bit less than what we had expected and as I just mentioned, more swift to the fourth quarter. We don't comment on the incremental sales by channel related to growth from our different channel activity outside of travel retail and online. But certainly, the incremental stores will contribute some to the growth in the fourth quarter, a pickup in performance in the U.S. is also expected to drive more of the fourth quarter growth as well, and in particular our bigger brands Estée Lauder and Clinique in addition to M-A-C.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Caroline Levy from CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question is from Caroline Levy from CLSA.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions I have to ask on China, of course. If you could talk a little bit about the shift in channels and obviously, online is doing really well. Could you talk about your strategy within department stores, how many freestanding stores you're
componenttext: Two quick questions I have to ask on China, of course. If you could talk a little bit about the shift in channels and obviously, online is doing really well. Could you talk about your strategy within department stores, how many freestanding stores you're opening beyond the Tier 1 cities and whether over time do you think freestanding stores will be throughout the country or online, how big could online get there? My second question is something on innovation on skin, I'm just wondering, if you're changing the way you look at that innovation, given the challenges to the growth in the category now?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so on China, we've been growing 5% of our net sales this quarter and 8% our retail sales. So retail sales 8% in China is good, it's strong. And the profile of our growth, first of all, by brand, is that all brands are growing double-digit, with the e
componenttext:
Yes, so on China, we've been growing 5% of our net sales this quarter and 8% our retail sales. So retail sales 8% in China is good, it's strong. And the profile of our growth, first of all, by brand, is that all brands are growing double-digit, with the exception of our Estée Lauder brand, which is a biggest brand and that's the profile. So we're -- first of all, even before distribution, we're diversifying our brand portfolio that goes with the distribution because different brands having different distribution. And we are diversifying geographically because as I explained our timing was through also this quarter we are opening in new cities and new geographical area of China. We opened one new city, we opened 30 new doors just in the quarter 3. In terms of the channels, online is doing well and will continue to do well. Today, we have now 10% of our business by now in online in China versus 12% in the U.S., so China is catching up with the U.S. at a speed of light. We're opening more freestanding store in this moment is mainly on M-A-C and Jo Malone, but in the future we may decide as we see the opportunity to add also other brands increasing the number of freestanding stores, particularly, in the cities where this is appropriate and there is no alternative distribution solutions. I personally believe that the future of freestanding stores in China will go directly to omnichannel meaning the stores will be connected to online brand.com activities and with the 1 basically omnichannel opportunity that will bring the brands in many more cities with pretty efficient freestanding store models, which are not the traditional big freestanding stores in cities like in the developed markets. And finally, we believe the specialty channel over time will also develop in China, and today, we are much more penetrated and developed in the specialty channel in China that we were in the U.S. at the beginning of the specialty channel development. So diversified by region of China, well diversified by brand or better diversified by brand in our strategy and well diversified by channel is our goal for the development of the China market.
Now in innovation on skin care, as I explained before, yes, we are looking at skin care in a different way reflecting the new consumer trends of reality. As I said, when you take skin care as a whole, there is a bigger and faster growth in what I call skin care for immediate benefit or skin care as a base of makeup and there is less growth in this moment in the intense antiaging skin care part. For the same reason, for makeup, a lot of the growth is driven by millionaires, which is more interested in this part of the skin care. So yes, big part of innovation pipeline is also driven in these skin care benefits, which are more modern  and more millionaire. Take an example, the new dimension of launch of Estée Lauder is not about antiaging, it's about really the shaping of the phase depending how consumer wants. So think of our fastest-growing skin care segment, which are masks. Masks or even we have a brand GLAMGLOW, which is completely focused on masks, and masks is product you use to get immediately after 10 minutes the benefit that you're looking for, be it luminosity, moisturization, or brightening, et cetera. So skin care for immediate benefits, which is closer to makeup in reality in terms of benefit to consumer is a fastest-growing trend, and our pipeline in these areas are the strongest they have ever been.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Joe Altobello from Raymond James.
componenttext: Our next question is from Joe Altobello from Raymond James.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First-person on Hong Kong. Fabrizio, you mentioned earlier that you think that's going to be a temporary phenomenon, but it's been going on now for 5 quarters or 6 quarters. Is there anything that you're seeing that at least you believe that should get be
componenttext: First-person on Hong Kong. Fabrizio, you mentioned earlier that you think that's going to be a temporary phenomenon, but it's been going on now for 5 quarters or 6 quarters. Is there anything that you're seeing that at least you believe that should get better anytime soon or that's going to be with us well into fiscal '17? And then shifting gears to skin care a little bit, you just mentioned, the new reality in that category, is there anything that can be done to reaccelerate the category or is that going to be demographically challenged for some time?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, okay. On Hong Kong, So I don't know what I don't know. I'm saying it's temporary because Hong Kong is a great market with an enormous internal demand of local consumers and is a very attractive market for Chinese, in general. So it's been declining s
componenttext: Yes, okay. On Hong Kong, So I don't know what I don't know. I'm saying it's temporary because Hong Kong is a great market with an enormous internal demand of local consumers and is a very attractive market for Chinese, in general. So it's been declining substantially in the last period. I believe at a certain moment, it will stabilize. I personally don't have the expectation that it will go back to big growth fast, but I do have the expectation that this trend will stabilize; will stabilize also because the local consumption is actually continue to increase, and so is the mix between the local consumption and tourists, particularly, Chinese tourist that at certain moment to stabilize. And I just came from Hong Kong, as I said in my prepared remarks, I was in Asia last week, I visited Hong Kong and Korea. And the other thing making me comfort is the strengths of our team there, which is managing this very difficult timing in a fantastic way, increasing their activities on a local consumers to help our business to stabilize without waiting for tourists, but just increasing our market share with locals, which I think is the right strategy and I have great confidence in our team to be able to stabilize the trend as soon as the market will allow. On your skin care question, I think is that -- I think, I have answered already several times, the skin care, obviously, is remains the most important categories overall and we'll continue to grow. As I said, the fastest-growing part of skin care is the skin care, which is more relating to immediate benefits, which is the skin care, which is of high interest for millennial. We had to adjust our innovation, our technology, our activities and planning for the future to the balance between more drastic antiaging benefits and more immediate benefits. We're doing that by our portfolio brands, some of our brands are much stronger in antiaging, like Estée Lauder, some of our other brands like GLAMGLOW are completely focused on immediate results skin care. And come of our brands, like Bobbi Brown, have a strong skin care business, which is actually the skin care is a basal makeup, it is to support to the makeup habits of women. So we have a packing skin care multiple fronts, antiaging, basal makeup, insta benefit. Thanks to our portfolio brands and thanks to our innovation pipeline. I feel very strong about our long-term skin care trends, but it's a fact that makeup, in this moment, is a much foster growing category, and we are again, I see as a strength, that we have the agility to adjust and refocus our investment resources depending on the biggest trend we are seeing.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Lauren Lieberman from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question is from Lauren Lieberman from Barclays.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one clarifying question on the door opening and second on the investment spending. So first on the doors, just I want to confirm that 250 is still the right number for this year, so there will be 135 doors opening roughly in the fourth quarter? And t
componenttext: Just one clarifying question on the door opening and second on the investment spending. So first on the doors, just I want to confirm that 250 is still the right number for this year, so there will be 135 doors opening roughly in the fourth quarter? And then secondly, if that's the case, that would actually suggest that a lot of the step up in spending budgeted for this year, is really affiliated with those doors, more so necessarily a specific step up in advertising. So if you comment on that, it's great. And within the AMS line, no I know its not reported quarterly, but on a full-year basis, if you could talk about how that mix has maybe shifted over time if there is some reduction in some buckets, like sampling or merchandising with and department stores, but at increasingly kind of core advertising dollars that would be really helpful?

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Lauren I'll start and then I'll let Fabrizio add. In terms of the door openings, you're right, approximately 130 in the fourth quarter, possibly, a little bit less. And yes, we do see and expect to see a step up in our store-related expenses, so sellin
componenttext: So Lauren I'll start and then I'll let Fabrizio add. In terms of the door openings, you're right, approximately 130 in the fourth quarter, possibly, a little bit less. And yes, we do see and expect to see a step up in our store-related expenses, so selling expenses, store ops expenses related to many of those store openings. We also do though, however, expect to see a step up in A&P expense related to some of the programs that we're supporting in the fourth quarter. And it runs the gamut in terms of the spend. Certainly, there are some sampling that's involved in that A&P spend. So we did talk about the fact that promotion was down in the third quarter. We do expect it to be more in the fourth quarter related to some of the programs that we're supporting.

headline: The Estée Lauder Companies Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and in term of advertising, I mean, we -- there is an increase of sampling to be very clear. Sampling, more and more important given the dynamic of the consumer, given also the channels that we are going in. There is an increase in loyalty programs a
componenttext: Yes, and in term of advertising, I mean, we -- there is an increase of sampling to be very clear. Sampling, more and more important given the dynamic of the consumer, given also the channels that we are going in. There is an increase in loyalty programs and in the ability to link consumers to loyalty activities, particularly, that goes along with freestanding stores and online and e-commerce, there is an increase of these -- and a decrease of all other kind of promotion, which are more typical of brick-and-mortar. And in terms, I would say you need to look at what's happening for us is like our magazine print advertising is more or less stabilizing, but our TV advertising is decreasing and is increasing of equivalent or more the digital social media addressing. So is -- summarizing is a stabilization of the magazine, advertising a decrease of television and an increase of the digital social media. That's the trends we are seeing. Now, obviously, this mix is very different by country in the word and by brand, but in general, this is a big trend we have seen. So more sampling and more digital social media.
